natural problem: What is the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of the fraction $\frac{1}{129}$?
natural solution: If we multiply this fraction by 10, we do not change any of the digits; we simply shift all the digits one place to the left.

Therefore, if we multiply the fraction by a sufficiently large power of 10, then the first digit obtained when dividing by 129 will be the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of $\frac{1}{129}$.
So the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of $\frac{1}{129}$ is $\boxed{7}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 1 / 129"
shows  "rightmost_digit x = 7"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of the fraction $\frac{1}{129}$? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 If we multiply this fraction by 10, we do not change any of the digits; we simply shift all the digits one place to the left.
 Therefore, if we multiply the fraction by a sufficiently large power of 10, then the first digit obtained when dividing by 129 will be the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of $\frac{1}{129}$.
 Observing that $100 < 129 < 1000$, we compute $\frac{1000}{129}=7 \frac{97}{129}$.
 So the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of $\frac{1}{129}$ is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 1 / 129"
shows  "rightmost_digit x = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: "Find the rightmost digit of the decimal representation of $\frac{1}{129}$. The final answer is 7."

 proof-

a_1.informal problem: Find the first digit after the decimal point when the real number $x$ is equal to $\frac{1}{129}$. The final answer is $7$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 1"
and h1 : "b = 129"
and h2 : "a/b = d"
and h3 : "d = truncate d + fractional_part d"
shows  "fractional_part d * 10 = 7"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of the fraction $\frac{1}{129}$? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 If we multiply this fraction by 10, we do not change any of the digits; we simply shift all the digits one place to the left.
 Therefore, if we multiply the fraction by a sufficiently large power of 10, then the first digit obtained when dividing by 129 will be the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of $\frac{1}{129}$.
 Observing that $100 < 129 < 1000$, we compute $\frac{1000}{129}=7 \frac{97}{129}$.
 So the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of $\frac{1}{129}$ is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 1"
and h1 : "b = 129"
and h2 : "a/b = d"
and h3 : "d = truncate d + fractional_part d"
shows  "fractional_part d * 10 = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the fractional part of the division of 1 by 129. Multiply this fractional part by 10. The final answer is 7.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 1 / 129"
shows  "frac x * 10 powr (1::nat) = 7"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of the fraction $\frac{1}{129}$? The final Answer is 7
 ### Proof
 If we multiply this fraction by 10, we do not change any of the digits; we simply shift all the digits one place to the left.
 Therefore, if we multiply the fraction by a sufficiently large power of 10, then the first digit obtained when dividing by 129 will be the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of $\frac{1}{129}$.
 Observing that $100 < 129 < 1000$, we compute $\frac{1000}{129}=7 \frac{97}{129}$.
 So the first nonzero digit to the right of the decimal point of $\frac{1}{129}$ is $\boxed{7}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 1 / 129"
shows  "frac x * 10 powr (1::nat) = 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If $x$ is equal to $\frac{1}{129}$, prove that the fractional part of $x$ multiplied by $10$ equals $7$.
